bills.description: The $6.7 billion general appropriation bill cuts funding for most state agencies to help make up the $1.3 billion shortfall.
Revokes the license of a physician performing an abortion.
Increase the state's tax on a pack of cigarettes by $1.50. The state estimates this would raise $158.4 million in FY17 and $190.1 million in FY18.
Requires motorists to pay a one-time $5 fee for the issuance of new license plates.
Caps the tax credit for economically at-risk oil and gas wells at $12.5 million a year. The state projects this will result in $120 million in savings for FY17.
Eliminates the refundable aspect of the Earned Income Tax Credit. The state projects this will result in $28.9 million in savings for FY17.
Eliminates the so-called "double deduction" income tax break. The state projects this will save $97 million in FY17.
Allows voters to decide on alcohol modernization reforms that include allowing grocery stores sell high-point beer.
Allows the state to take out $200 million in transportation bonds.
Gives district attorneys discretion to file a charge as a misdemeanor rather than a felony for certain crimes.
Creates a new crime to intentionally disseminate an image of another person engaged in a sexual act or whose intimate parts are exposed with the intent to harass or humiliate the person.

Calls for a convention of the states to propose Constitutional amendments to create a federal balanced budget requirement, create federal term limits and limit the power and jurisdiction of the federal government.
